frameDefinitions: A Potential_hindrance or an Agent (via their actions) keeps an Event from taking place, or despite the possibility of prevent the Event, do not do so.
An Agent leaves behind a Theme effectively rendering it no longer within their control or of the normal security as one's property.

The words in this frame describe situations in which a Perpetrator carries off and holds the Victim against his or her will by force. '' 'Two men kidnapped a Millwall soccer club employee, police said last night.'
These are words describing situations in which a Perpetrator takes Goods from a  Victim or a Source.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.

The words in this frame describe situations in which a Perpetrator forcibly seizes control over a Victim's Vehicle to gain some end.  '' 'French farmers have hijacked a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.'
frameExamples: Rain <t>prevented</t> the ball game from taking place.
Carolyn <t>abandoned</t> her car and jumped on a red double decker bus.
Two men <t>kidnapped</t> a Millwall soccer club employee, police said last night.
I can't believe he <t>pickpocketed</t> my gold watch !
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
French farmers have <t>hijacked</t> a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> is the force which keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from happening, or does not.
The <fen>Event</fen> is prevented from occurring by the <fen>Preventing_cause</fen> or the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the sentient being which keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from happening.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> or <fen>Agent</fen> keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from taking place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> or <fen>Agent</fen> keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from taking place.
The <fex name='Agent'>Agent</fex> is the person who acts to leave behind the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The <fex name='Theme'>Theme</fex> is the entity that is relinguished to no one from the <fex name='Agent'>Agent</fex>'s possession.
When the <fen>Agent</fen> gives up the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> gives up the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The <fen>Perpetrator</fen> is the person (or other agent) who carries off and holds the <fen>Victim</fen> against his or her will.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the person who is carried off and held against his/her will.
When the kidnapping occurs.
Where the kidnapping takes place.
<fen>Perpetrator</fen> is the person (or other agent) that takes the goods away.
<fen>Victim</fen> is the person (or other sentient being or group) that owns the goods before they are taken away by the perpetrator.
<fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
<fen>Source</fen> is the initial location of the goods, before they change location.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the theft occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the theft occurs.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
This is the person (or other agent) who forcibly seizes control over a vehicle to gain some end.
This is the means of transportation which gets under the control of the perpetrator. Example: The terrorists hijacked <fex name='Vehicle'>the plane</fex>.
This role describes the people that are suffering as a result of the <fen>Perpetrator</fen>'s action.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: Leslie stole the watch <fex>from the table</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>at dusk</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>in the park</fex>.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
The rebels skyjacked a plane <fex>with 89 passangers</fex>.
